item.title: Sri Lanka on High Alert as Cyclone Death Toll Reaches 56
item.description: Heavy rainfall was forecast for nearly all of the island nation as Cyclone Ditwah churned northwest toward India.
item.dc:creator: Pamodi Waravita

media:content.media:credit: Eranga Jayawardena/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Storm damage in Colombo, Sri Lanka’s capital, on Friday.

item.title: In Turkey, Pope Seeks to Soothe an Ancient Christian Divide
item.description: In Istanbul, Pope Leo XIV will meet the patriarch of the Eastern Orthodox Church to show amity between two of the world’s largest Christian groups.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard

media:content.media:credit: Bradley Secker for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Tourists light candles during a visit to the Theological School of Halki, an Orthodox seminary shuttered by the Turkish government.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Climate ‘Shock’ is Eating Away at Home Values
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 28, 2025.

item.title: Did Myanmar’s Junta Demolish Scam Centers Just for Show?
item.description: Myanmar’s junta made a grand display of demolishing buildings that hosted the centers, even broadcasting the explosions. But the scammers have found new homes.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee

media:content.media:credit: Lillian Suwanrumpha/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: KK Park, a large scam center in eastern Myanmar, seen from Mae Sot District in Thailand in September.

item.title: Dirigió Finlandia durante la covid y las amenazas rusas. Pero es famosa por un baile
item.description: Sanna Marin was celebrated as a pathbreaking feminist when she became Finland’s prime minister at age 34. Two years after leaving office, she’s trying to turn a scandal over a leaked dancing video into a battle cry.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Blair, Tony, Institute for Global Change

media:content.media:credit: Juho Kuva para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Al final, el escándalo le dio a Sanna Marin más renombre mundial que a la mayoría de los políticos finlandeses.

item.title: Their Obsession With Travel Points Led to an Unexpected Spark
item.description: Heather Peggs and George Igoe connected over frequent flier miles, but their chemistry sealed the deal. After their first date, she deleted her dating apps, and a month in, he knew she was “the one.”
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora

item.title: The Three Times I Married My Wife
item.description: Saying wedding vows is one thing. Living up to them is quite another.
item.dc:creator: Brent Chaim Spodek

media:content.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: The Federal Shutdown Almost Delayed Their Marriage
item.description: Jared Brown and Daniel Roberts, who bonded over their work with the Obamas, had a meticulous engagement “rollout plan,” but securing a marriage license was the real test.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova

item.title: At 90 and 83, They Leaped Into Love Again
item.description: Marvin Hersel, a Navy veteran, and Maria Chavez, a retired medical translator from Mexico, fell in love at their senior living residence after swapping vivid childhood stories.
item.dc:creator: Emily Lang

media:content.media:credit: World Photo/Jacob Ford

item.title: A New Orleans Processional at a Grand Old Irish Estate
item.description: Morgan Evans and Colm Browne arrived at their wedding welcome party in Ireland in a second line led by a Dublin band.
item.dc:creator: Rosalie R. Radomsky

item.title: Trump Uses National Guard Shooting to Cast Suspicion on Refugees
item.description: President Trump claimed there were “a lot of problems with Afghans,” without providing evidence, as his administration announced that it was implementing new immigration guidelines.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump held a video call to thank members of the military for their service on Thursday.

item.title: National Guard Member Dies After Shooting Near White House
item.description: Army Specialist Sarah Beckstrom, a 20-year-old member of the West Virginia Army National Guard, died on Thursday from wounds suffered in an ambush. President Trump said she was “outstanding in every way.”
item.dc:creator: Shawn Paik
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A small memorial at the site of the shooting of two National Guard members in Washington, on Thursday.

item.title: For Shooting Suspect, a Long Path of Conflict From Afghanistan to America
item.description: Rahmanullah Lakanwal was among the Afghans who came to the United States after the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan. Earlier, he served in a paramilitary unit that worked with U.S. forces.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson, Hamed Aleaziz and Jack Healy

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Nov. 28, 2025
item.description: Jacob McDermott opens our solving weekend.
item.dc:creator: Isaac Aronow

media:content.media:credit: Alex Slitz/Getty Images

item.title: Recent Afghan Arrivals Fear Their Futures in the U.S. Are Now in Jeopardy
item.description: Many are anxious after the Trump administration vowed to undertake sweeping reviews of immigrants after the shooting of two National Guard troops.
item.dc:creator: Allison McCann and Pooja Salhotra

media:content.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Afghans gathered at the National Conference Center in Leesburg, Va., which served as a temporary shelter site during Operation Allies Welcome in 2022.

item.title: SNAP Helping Families Put Thanksgiving Dinner on the Table
item.description: SNAP benefits helped Leanna Nieves of Haverhill, Mass., buy Thanksgiving dinner for her family, but she used the day to set aside what have been chronic worries about the federal program.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Russell

media:content.media:credit: Cassandra Klos for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Leanna Nieves prepared a Thanksgiving meal with her friend Angelica, left, and Angelica’s daughter, Deannjellyk, at her home in Haverhill, Mass.

item.title: Tiroteo en Washington: esto sabemos del sospechoso
item.description: El presunto autor del tiroteo fue miembro de fuerzas especiales en la provincia de Kandahar calificadas por grupos de derechos humanos como “escuadrones de la muerte”.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Hamed Aleaziz, Elian Peltier and Safiullah Padshah

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Fuerzas de seguridad en el lugar del tiroteo. El sospechoso había trabajado con una unidad militar apoyada por la CIA en Afganistán.

item.title: The Uniquely American Heartbreak of Yet Another Tragedy
item.description: The National Guard members shot in Washington are the latest victims of a political violence permeating our society.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Federal Takeover of Metropolitan Police Dept (DC)

media:content.media:credit: Mark Schiefelbein/Associated Press

item.title: La información de EE. UU. sobre los ataques a embarcaciones es limitada
item.description: El ejército sabe que en los barcos va alguien que tiene una conexión con un cártel de la droga, pero en la mayoría de los ataques el Pentágono no sabe con precisión a quién está matando.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Las lecciones de la larga guerra contra el terrorismo parecen haberse dejado de lado mientras el gobierno de Trump ataca barcos en el Caribe y el Pacífico oriental que, según afirma, transportan drogas.

item.title: Carney Lifts Climate Laws for New Alberta Pipeline
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney reached a tentative deal with the province as part of his program to curb the country’s economic dependence on the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen

media:content.media:credit: Todd Korol/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney with Premier Danielle Smith of Alberta on Thursday in Calgary.

item.title: Louvre Raising Ticket Prices for Non-European Visitors
item.description: From Jan. 14, visitors to the museum from outside the European Economic Area will pay 45 percent more for entry to help finance its ambitious renovation plan.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic and Alex Marshall

media:content.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Louvre is still on the mend after thieves broke into one of its galleries in October and stole about $100 million worth of jewelry.

item.title: Officials Identify National Guard Shooting Suspect
item.description: Officials said the gunman immigrated from Afghanistan in 2021 after working with C.I.A.-backed military units. The suspect drove across the country to carry out the attack. The two wounded members of the National Guard remain in critical condition.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Mitssunaga

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A photograph of Rahmanullah Lakanwal, right, was displayed next to the two victims at a news conference.

item.title: A.I. and the Trillion-Dollar Question
item.description: Even the companies building the technology don’t seem exactly sure where it’s headed.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The chip-making giant Nvidia’s valuation topped $5 trillion last month.

item.title: Ruth Thorne-Thomsen, Photographer of Dreamlike Tableaux, Dies at 82
item.description: Using a pinhole camera, she captured miniature landscapes that she had fashioned to resemble surreal versions of 19th-century travel photos.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

media:content.media:credit: via Ruth Thorne-Thomsen Archive
media:content.media:description: Ruth Thorne-Thomsen in an undated photo. When a friend gave her a pinhole camera in graduate school, “I knew immediately that this was it,” she said. “It was the blueprint, the matrix, for everything that followed.”

item.title: A Bunch of People Are Out of Town, Let’s Feast!
item.description: Four restaurants to check out before the holiday crowds descend in full force.
item.dc:creator: Luke Fortney

media:content.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times

item.title: El papa León visita Turquía en su primer viaje como pontífice
item.description: El papa inició un viaje de seis días, que también incluirá una visita a Líbano.

media:content.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El papa León XIV en el Mausoleo de Ataturk en Ankara, Turquía

item.title: Why Is the U.S. Threatening Venezuela?
item.description: Venezuela doesn’t play a large role in the drug trade to the United States, so what is motivating the massive military buildup? Julian E. Barnes, who reports on intelligence and international security, discusses the issues with our senior writer Katrin Bennhold.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Katrin Bennhold, Nikolay Nikolov, Leila Medina, Lazaro Gamio, Samuel Granados and Stephanie Swart

item.title: D.C. Shooting: What We Know About the National Guard Victims
item.description: The family of one of the West Virginia National Guard members was at her side before she died on Thursday. A man at the other member’s home asked for prayers for his son.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales, Kevin Williams and Bernard Mokam

item.title: U.S. Reviews Biden Asylum Cases After Shooting
item.description: A Homeland Security Department spokeswoman accused the previous administration of failing to vet asylum applicants “on a massive scale.”
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz and Minho Kim

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A small memorial left at the scene of the shooting of two National Guard members in Washington, shown on Thursday.

item.title: Una llamada filtrada del enviado especial de la Casa Blanca muestra deferencia a Rusia
item.description: La transcripción desató la indignación en Washington porque Steve Witkoff parecía estar mostrando al Kremlin cómo negociar con Trump y socavar una visita del presidente de Ucrania.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El rostro de Steve de Witkoff se veía tras la imagen borrosa de una persona con traje azul y corbata roja.

item.title: What to Know About the Coup in Guinea-Bissau
item.description: The opposition has accused the president of putting a general in charge of the government so that he could stay in power and lead by proxy.
item.dc:creator: Saikou Jammeh and Ruth Maclean
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

media:content.media:credit: Patrick Meinhardt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: General Horta Inta-a during his swearing-in ceremony as the transitional leader of Guinea-Bissau.

item.title: El peor incendio de Hong Kong en décadas impulsa una revisión de la seguridad
item.description: Las autoridades dijeron que unas redes y unas planchas de espuma inflamables podrían haber provocado el incendio más mortífero de la ciudad en casi 70 años.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Joy Dong, Tiffany May and Keith Bradsher

item.title: The Nigerian Musician Championed by Zohran Mamdani
item.description: Our critic’s latest Song of the Week is by ODUMODUBLVCK, an artist who embodies the full spectrum of Nigerian Afrobeats.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica, Joe Coscarelli and Arjun Srivatsa

item.title: Pope Leo Visits Mideast on First Foreign Trip as Pontiff
item.description: Pope Leo XIV landed in Muslim-majority Turkey on Thursday, beginning the first international trip of his papacy. The voyage is aimed at promoting interfaith dialogue and cooperation between Christian groups.
item.dc:creator: Monika Cvorak

media:content.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Pope Leo XIV on Thursday visited the mausoleum of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey and its first president.

item.title: Winter Storm in Northern U.S. Expected to Snarl Post-Thanksgiving Travel
item.description: Forecasters say a winter storm could disrupt travel, dumping up to a foot of snow across parts of the Midwest through the holiday weekend.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar

media:content.media:credit: Stephen Maturen/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Minneapolis-Saint Paul International Airport on Thursday.

item.title: Here’s a Look at the D.C. Shooting Suspect’s C.I.A.-Backed Unit in Afghanistan
item.description: The units were backed by the C.I.A. and trained to conduct missions in Afghanistan during the U.S. war in the country.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe, Elian Peltier, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Fahim Abed
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: At New York City Ballet’s ‘Nutcracker,’ Bring on Fritz and Brat Winter
item.description: At New York City Ballet, two boys from the School of American Ballet get to play a coveted role: Fritz, a terror of a little brother.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas and Thea Traff
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Thea Traff for The New York Times

item.title: How a Rediscovered Klimt Got Swept Up in an International Dispute
item.description: The Viennese painter’s portrait of a West African prince was owned by a Jewish family who fled the Nazi occupation. It was then taken to Hungary, which has now moved to block a sale by an Austrian gallery.
item.dc:creator: Scott Reyburn

media:content.media:credit: Marcel Van Hoorn/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The Gustav Klimt painting of Prince William Nii Nortey Dowuona on display earlier this year.

item.title: Putin Defends Witkoff Against Accusations of Pro-Russia Bias
item.description: The Russian leader called the U.S. special envoy “an intelligent man” who is properly representing his country in peace negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne

media:content.media:credit: Gavriil Grigorov/Sputnik, via Reuters
media:content.media:description: A photo released by Russian state media showed President Vladimir V. Putin meeting with Steve Witkoff in Moscow in August. The two are scheduled to meet again next week.

item.title: Tiroteo a soldados de la Guardia Nacional en Washington: esto sabemos
item.description: Dos miembros de la Guardia Nacional resultaron gravemente heridos después de que un hombre les disparara cerca de la Casa Blanca. El presidente Trump calificó el tiroteo de acto terrorista.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Dos miembros de la Guardia Nacional resultaron gravemente heridos en un tiroteo ocurrido el miércoles cerca de la Casa Blanca.

item.title: U.S. Has Limited Knowledge of Those It Kills in Boat Strikes
item.description: The U.S. military has killed more than 80 people since the campaign began in early September. But it does not know who specifically is being killed.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Lessons of the long war against terrorism appear to have been cast aside as the Trump administration attacks boats in the Caribbean and the eastern Pacific that it says are carrying drugs.

item.title: Robert A.M. Stern, Architect Who Reinvented Prewar Splendor, Dies at 86
item.description: He designed museums, schools and libraries before winning international acclaim late in life for 15 Central Park West in Manhattan, hailed as a rebirth of the luxury apartment building.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden

media:content.media:credit: Richard Perry/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Robert A.M. Stern in 2007. Glowing reviews drove a stampede of celebrities to 15 CPW — the building he described as “my breakthrough” — overshadowing the competition from sleek glass towers that had been the rage in Manhattan early in the new millennium.

item.title: Hong Kong Residents Reel From Deadliest Fire in Decades
item.description: Dozens were killed in a fire that engulfed several apartment buildings in Hong Kong. Firefighters were still battling the blaze on Thursday, and dozens of people were still missing.
item.dc:creator: Nader Ibrahim, Tiffany May and Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times

item.title: Your Turkey Is Done at 165 Degrees, and More Thanksgiving Advice
item.description: And more Thanksgiving Day affirmations, tips, snacks and drinks (margs, anyone?).
item.dc:creator: Emily Weinstein

media:content.media:credit: Christopher Testani for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.
media:content.media:description: Rosie Schaap’s margaritas.

item.title: Russia Labels Navalny’s Anti-Corruption Group as Terrorist Organization
item.description: A legal assault against the opposition leader’s movement has deepened since his death in prison last year.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Vasilyeva

media:content.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Flowers and other tributes left on Aleksei A. Navalny’s grave in Moscow after he died in an Arctic penal colony last year.

item.title: Rocket Attack on Iraqi Gas Field Cuts Power to Most of Kurdistan
item.description: The strike is the latest in a string of attacks on energy infrastructure in Iraq’s northern Kurdish region, which some regional authorities have privately blamed on Iran-affiliated militias.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

media:content.media:credit: Ako Rasheed/Reuters
media:content.media:description: The Khor Mor gas field after a rocket attack in Iraq’s Kurdistan region on Thursday.

item.title: Entrevistas para la ‘green card’ de Estados Unidos terminan en arresto para unos cónyuges
item.description: Los agentes están deteniendo a cónyuges nacidos en el extranjero durante el último paso para obtener la residencia permanente. Los acusan de infracciones en sus visas que podrían terminar en una deportación.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan and Ariana Drehsler

media:content.media:description: Stephen Paul had to take a leave from his job at the San Diego County Sheriff’s Department to care for his child while his wife was detained by ICE.
